relation: Some studies find that the risk of death is as much as __ times higher than normal in the first year after the death of a spouse.
Who have the highest suicide rates?
Most frequent cause of death in childhood/adolescents
The absence of a heartbeat and breathing
A diagnosis of death based on the cessation of all signs of brain activity, as measured by electrical brain waves.
The unexplained death of a seemingly health baby
People who study death and dying
Denial (shock), Anger (emotion), Bargaining, Depression (reactive or preparatory), and Acceptance.
People feel sadness over future losses. Example: end to relationships with others, and not able to see future generations

The feelings of sadness are based on events that have already occurred. Example: the loss of dignity that may accompany medical procedures, the end of a job, or the knowledge that one will never return from the hospital to one's home.
A legal document designating what medical treatments people want or do not want if they cannot express their wishes (including DNR)
The practice of assisting people who are terminally ill to die more quickly
An alternative to hospitalization in which dying people stay in their homes and receive treatment from their families and visiting medical staff.
Care provided for the dying in institutions devoted to those who are terminally ill.
Acknowledgement of the objective fact that one has experienced a death.
The emotional response to one's loss. Entails shock, numbness, disbelief, or outright denial and may continue on with regular routines.
A type of mourning that continues unceasingly for months and years.
Not applicable to a groups of people or situations, because they may go through steps in different order or ways.
When a person provides means for a patient to commit suicide- Dr. Kavorkian
Patient asks that no extraordinary care be given
Patient asks to be helped to die (mercy killing?)
An adult other than the patient requests that no extraordinary treatment be given
